subject: Re: [junit] Not knowing the tests in advance when providing a test runner
msgSnippet: All, I m not sure how I sent this to the entire list.  My sincere apologies to Cedric and the list for giving this signficantly more airtime than I intended
messageBody:
All,

I'm not sure how I sent this to the entire list. My sincere apologies
to Cedric and the list for giving this signficantly more airtime than
I intended for what I intended as a personal mail.

David Saff

On Wed, Jun 29, 2011 at 9:49 AM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
> Cedric,
>
> I'm sure it's important to both of us that people get the best
> information about the testing options available to them.  In general,
> I'm not sure how many people asking how to do something in JUnit want
> to hear about how to do it in another framework, but I'll go along
> with the idea that it's worth mentioning it.
>
> However, if you're unclear on any part of how _JUnit_ works, and want
> to be helpful to users, feel free to run it past me personally before
> accidentally misinforming the whole list.
>
> Thanks,
>
>   David Saff
>
> 2011/6/27 Cédric Beust ♔ <cedric@...>:
>> On Fri, Jun 24, 2011 at 2:36 PM, Bill Venners <bill@...> wrote:
>>
>>> The skipped concept shows up in JUnit as assumptions, and in TestNG as
>>> dependent tests, I think.
>>>
>>
>> I think that JUnit marks tests that fail their assumption as "Failed", while
>> TestNG marks them as "Skipped" (a status which doesn't exist in JUnit
>> AFAIK).
>>
>> --
>> Cédric
>>
>>
>> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>>
